{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3528687,"name":"James","username":"JamerGamer789","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19b73/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-16T15:05:33.830Z","cooked":"

Our team has just started our initial testing and first practice cycles. The problem is our elevator is pretty slow, and I’m wondering if it is a PID issue, gearbox, or underpowered motors. We have 2 Neos with a 12:1 reduction but we have to wait a while before we get to L4 or L3. I know this is a pretty general question with not a lot of detail. I don’t know too much about the mechanical aspects but I’m trying to learn and give our team’s robot the best chance at districts. Thanks!

I’m not the most knowledgeable about software, but this year my team is running our elevator 5:1 off of one Kraken and in testing have thus far had no issues. Double NEOs could probably easily handle a smaller reduction.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-16T15:08:11.419Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":343,"readers_count":342,"score":68.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491922,"topic_slug":"making-elevator-faster","display_username":"Atley Carman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71860,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/making-elevator-faster/491922/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3528719,"name":"Jared Van Horn","username":"CuteRedpandas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cuteredpandas/{size}/243322_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-16T15:33:00.399Z","cooked":"

yall can 100% reduce your gear ratio a bit to increase speed. that might not be a good idea if you’re trying to climb with your elevator too but if you aren’t lifting massive loads you can reduce the ratio to more like ~5:1

How many stages is your elevator?

My team has almost the exact same setup as you: 2 NEO Vortexs with a 12:1 gear reduction. We have a 3-stage elevator, and the result is that the elevator is extremely fast. But if you only have a 1 or 2 stage elevator, your results may be different.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-16T15:48:32.154Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":273,"readers_count":272,"score":59.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":491922,"topic_slug":"making-elevator-faster","display_username":"John Bottenberg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12266,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67"},"post_url":"/t/making-elevator-faster/491922/4","custom_user_title":"3142, 8706, 714←4973←2930←3322←67","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3528729,"name":"Mentor","username":"Kevin_Thorp","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kevin_thorp/{size}/186120_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-16T15:49:36.469Z","cooked":"

Have you installed constant force springs? If not your motors are working much harder extending vs. retracting. FRC teams get a voucher for 6 free springs from Vulcan Spring).

You can also put a wrench on your hex shaft (with power off) to check for excessive friction.

How are you driving it in software? Post your code? 12:1 is probably a little stronger than it needs to be but never the less that should still be able to fly.

Properties of your system are going to matter a lot.

  • Travel Length, Spool Diameter, Payload Weight. ETC…

Recalc is supper helpful for estimating these things:

reca.lc

ReCalc

ReCalc - a collaboration focused mechanical design calculator.

Thank you for all the responses. I’ll answer some of the questions here:

  1. We had constant force springs but we are very tight on weight so we removed them. We are still trying to make the weight for an Algae intake (we are very close now :))
  2. We have a 3 stage elevator, but I’m not super sure on the mechanical specifics.
  3. We are using PID control for our elevator. Today I’ll do some tests to see if we are indeed hitting our maximum speed. Here is our code regardless: 2025-Reefscape-Competition/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ElevatorSubsystem.java at main · FRC3546/2025-Reefscape-Competition · GitHub

Thanks for the suggestion for Recalc, I’ll definetly check it out!

JamerGamer789:

We are using PID control for our elevator. Today I’ll do some tests to see if we are indeed hitting our maximum speed. Here is our code regardless: 2025-Reefscape-Competition/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ElevatorSubsystem.java at main · FRC3546/2025-Reefscape-Competition · GitHub

An easy test you could do today is just running the motor open loop with a voltage out command. That pretty much would tell you what kind of speed you are capable of.

You might also look into a profiled pid controller. Such as the WPILIB one or REVs MaxMotion. That lets you have more control over the motion (within achievable values…)

What are the advantages of a profiled PID controller compared to the traditional one?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-16T17:15:34.377Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":137,"readers_count":136,"score":37.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":491922,"topic_slug":"making-elevator-faster","display_username":"James","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":20003,"username":"joemost","name":"joemost","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joemost/{size}/11114_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51278,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/making-elevator-faster/491922/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529013,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-16T20:42:54.147Z","cooked":"

a properly tuned motion profile allows you to hit higher accelerations and velocities without putting excess strain on your system. A Profiled PID (and other profiles) run a “traditional pid” under the hood, but work by controlling the setpoint changes.

With just a raw PID (or “traditional PID”), your system will experience immense forces when you change setpoints, and large forces again when it hits the target setpoint as it tries to stop the system. Normally, to make your bot not instantly explode, the resolution is reduce the response of the PID, resulting in reduced performance.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-02-16T20:42:54.316Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":37.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":491922,"topic_slug":"making-elevator-faster","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51278,"username":"JamerGamer789","name":"James","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19b73/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":"Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.","can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/making-elevator-faster/491922/10","custom_user_title":"2811 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3529016,"name":"Arshan","username":"arshan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arshan/{size}/219045_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-16T20:45:06.893Z","cooked":"
JamerGamer789:

What are the advantages of a profiled PID controller compared to the traditional one?

Profiled PID controllers generate a full motion profile by breaking down the setpoint to your target into a series of sub-setpoints with defined physical constraints (like maximum velocity, acceleration, and error tolerance). This can reduce mechanical stress and stability since now you have more control over the motion of the mechanism.

A traditional PID controller simply reacts to the error between the current state and the target setpoint in contrast to the smooth path generated by a profiled controller.

Thus a regular PID controller can result in abrupt movements and less predictable behavior, especially when the system’s dynamics (like inertia or friction) are significant.
